contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this is a metaphor representing Yahweh giving Jeremiah special authority to speak. AT: "Then it was as though Yahweh touched my mouth" (UDB) or 2) Jeremiah was seeing a vision and Yahweh actually did this as a symbolic act of giving Jeremiah authority to speak. AT: "Then Yahweh touched my mouth with his hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: Then Yahweh reached out with his hand, touched my mouth

contextId.information: This represents guaranteeing that he will do what he has said. AT: "I am remembering my word to carry it out" or "I guarantee that I will do what I have said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am watching over my word to carry it out

contextId.information: "Disaster will be let loose from the north." This represents God causing disaster to come from the north to the south. AT: "Disaster will come from the north" or "I will send disaster from the north" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Disaster will be opened up out of the north

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this represents ruling over Jerusalem. AT: "will rule at the gates of Jerusalem. or 2) this represents judging Jerusalem. AT: "will judge Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will set his throne at the entrance of the gates of Jerusalem

contextId.information: Here "be shattered" represents  being extremely afraid, and "shatter" represents causing Jeremiah to be extremely afraid. AT: "Do not be terrified ... I will terrify you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not be shattered ... I will shatter you

contextId.information: Being strong like these things represents being confident and unchanging in saying what God had told him to say. AT: "I have made you strong against the whole land like a fortified city, an iron pillar, and bronze walls" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Today I have made you a fortified city, an iron pillar, and bronze walls against the whole land

contextId.information: A "land of drought" is a land that does not have enough water. Here "deep darkness" is a metaphor for danger. AT: "a dangerous land where there is not enough water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a land of drought and deep darkness

contextId.information: Here "become plunder" represents being attacked and taken as captives to another country. AT: "So why has Israel been taken away as captives" or "So why have Israel's enemies taken Israel away as captives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: So why has he become plunder

contextId.information: Here "drink the waters" of these two rivers is a metaphor for relying on the armies of Egypt and Assyria to help them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and drink the waters of Shihor ... and drink the waters of the Euphrates River

contextId.information: God speaks of Israel worshiping other gods as if they were a wild female donkey running to find male donkeys. AT: "You are like a young female donkey that lives in the desert. When she wants to mate she is out of control and constantly sniffs the breeze to find a mate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a wild donkey accustomed to the wilderness, in her heat sniffing the wind

contextId.information: God speaks of Israel wanting to worship other gods as if they were running around in the desert looking for those gods. AT: "I have told you to stop running here and there chasing after false gods, because all that it does is wear out your sandals and make you very thirsty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You must restrain your feet from becoming bare and your throat from being thirsty!

contextId.information: Here "accept discipline" represents learning from discipline. AT: "They refused to learn from discipline" or "When I disciplined them, they refused to learn to obey me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They would not accept discipline

contextId.information: God speaks of Israel and Judah as if they were sisters. AT: "the people of Judah, who also did not obey me, saw" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: her faithless sister Judah saw

contextId.information: Here "defiled" represents making the land unacceptable to God. They did this by sinning against him there when they worshiped idols. AT: "she made my land no good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: she defiled the land

contextId.information: Here "stones and trees" represents stone and wood as material that was sculpted into images of idols. The people's idol worship is spoken of as if were committing adultery. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: she committed adultery with stones and trees

contextId.information: God speaks of Israel belonging to him as if Israel were his wife and he were Israel's husband. AT:  "for I am your husband" or "for you belong to me as a wife belongs to her husband" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for I have married you!

contextId.information: The word "you" refers to the people of Israel. The phrase "bear fruit" is a metaphor for having many descendants. AT: "you will increase greatly in number" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: you will increase and bear fruit

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of people's actions as if the people were walking along a path. Here the word "hearts" represents their minds or wills. AT: "They will no longer stubbornly do the wicked things that they want to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: They will no longer walk in the stubbornness of their wicked hearts

contextId.information: God speaks of giving them the land to possess forever as if it were an inheritance. AT: "the land that I gave to your ancestors so that it would belong to their descendants forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the land that I gave your ancestors as an inheritance

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "heal you of treachery" represents causing Israel to stop being unfaithful to God. AT: "I will cause you to stop being unfaithful to me" or 2) "heal you of treachery" represents forgiving Israel for being unfaithful. AT: "I will forgive your treachery" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will heal you of treachery!

contextId.information: Yahweh describes the people's devotion to him in terms of the physical sign of covenant. AT: "Dedicate yourselves completely to Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Be circumcised to Yahweh and remove the foreskins of your heart

contextId.information: AT: "A powerful and merciless army approaches" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A lion is coming

contextId.information: These are dangerous animals that can kill people. Possible meanings are 1) "Wild animals will come and kill people" or 2) "an enemy army will come and kill people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: So a lion ... A wolf ... A lurking panther

contextId.information: Male horses neigh loudly to female horses when they want to sleep with them. AT: "Each man was trying to sleep with his neighbor's wife." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Each man neighed to his neighbor's wife

contextId.information: Kings were often spoken of as shepherds of their people. AT: The kings and their soldiers will surround Jerusalem." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The shepherds and their flocks will go to them

contextId.information: Yahweh compares the people who remain after the enemy has already destroyed Israel to grapes that are left in a vineyard that people have already harvested. AT: "They will certainly come back to attack the people who remain in Israel after they have already destroyed it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will certainly glean those who are left in Israel like a vineyard

contextId.information: The prophets and the priests treat the sins of the people of Israel as though they were a small wound. AT: "as though it were not serious." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lightly

contextId.information: The paths and roads refer to the way that people live their lives. Yahweh wants the people of Israel to ask what would be a good way to live their lives and for them to live that way. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Stand at the road crossing ... We will not go

contextId.information: Yahweh describes the prophets as watchmen who were sent to warn the people of danger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I appointed for you watchmen ... will not listen

contextId.information: "and so they turned their backs to me and not their faces." AT: "and so they refused to pay attention to me, instead of eagerly obeying me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so they went backwards, not forward

contextId.information: The snakes represent the enemy soldiers. AT: "I am sending out enemy soldiers to fight you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am sending out snakes among you

contextId.information: Telling lies is spoken of as being done by the tongues of the wicked. Also, since a spoken lie cannot be taken back, telling lies is spoken of as if it were shooting arrows. Men shooting bows must step on their bows in order to fasten the bowstrings, so liars are referred to here as if they were stringing their bows using their tongues. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They tread on their bows of lies with their tongues

contextId.information: Committing one evil action after another is spoken of as if the evildoers were going from one action to another. AT: "They keep doing evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They go from wicked act to another

contextId.information: The tongue hurts people with lies in the same way that sharpened arrows hurt people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Their tongues are sharpened arrows

contextId.information: The enemy has completely destroyed my city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: My tent is devastated, and all of my tent cords are cut in two

contextId.information: This speaks of the horrible circumstances and oppression the Israelites were living in in Egypt by comparing them to a smelting furnace. AT: "of Egypt. What happened to them in Egypt was terrible; it was as though they were living in a hot furnace" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: from the land of Egypt, from the furnace for smelting iron

contextId.information: "the land where milk and honey flow." God spoke of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants were flowing through the land. AT: "the land that is excellent for raising livestock and growing crops" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the land flowing with milk and honey

contextId.information: In the Old Testament people were often compared to trees or plants. Those who were prosperous and healthy were spoken of as leafy, fruitful tree. AT: "In the past Yahweh said that you were like a leafy olive tree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In the past Yahweh called you a leafy olive tree

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh placing the people of Israel and Judah in the places where they live as if they were a tree that Yahweh had planted. AT: "who planted you like a farmer plants a tree" or "the one who placed you to live in the land of Israel and Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the one who planted you

contextId.information: The refers to Yahweh revealing to Jeremiah that his enemies were planning to kill him. This is spoken of here as if Jeremiah has already see their actions. AT: "have revealed to me their evil plans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: made me see their deeds

contextId.information: Here Jeremiah speaks of the wicked as if they were fruit trees. AT: "They are like fruit trees that you planted, that you allow to prosper and produce lots of fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You planted them and they took root. They continue to produce fruit

contextId.information: The two phrases are metaphors in which Yahweh speaks of his people as if they were his "house" and his "inheritance." AT: "I have abandoned my Israelite people, the people whom I chose to belong to me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have abandoned my house; I have forsaken my inheritance

contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks of his people being in danger and surrounded by their enemies as if they were a speckled bird surrounded by birds of prey. AT: "has become like a speckled bird, and her enemies are like birds of prey attacking her on all sides" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: become a speckled bird, that other birds of prey go against her all around

contextId.information: God speaks of forcing the people to leave their land as if they were plants that he was uprooting. See how you translated this concept in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:09|1:10]]. AT: "to make them leave their own land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to uproot them from their own ground

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. This speaks of the people becoming prosperous as if they were a building that was being built. AT: "I will build them up in the midst of my people" or "I will make them wealthy and they will live among my people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: they will be built up in the midst of my people

contextId.information: This speaks of goodness and blessings as "light" and of trouble and despair as "darkness." AT: "For you were hoping for light and blessings, but Yahweh will give you darkness and great despair--you will feel like you are surround by a dark cloud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For you are hoping for light, but he will turn the place into a deep darkness, into a dark cloud

contextId.information: Here Judah's "gates" represents Judah's cities, and Judah's cities represent the people who live in them. AT: "let her cities fall apart" or "let her people become weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let her gates fall apart

contextId.information: Here visions and divination are spoken of as if they were objects that could go from one place to another. AT: "deceitful visions and useless, deceitful divination that these prophets themselves have imagined"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: deceitful visions and useless, deceitful divination coming from their own minds

contextId.information: Here minds are spoken of as if they were a place instead of the ability to think of ideas.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their own minds

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of no longer acting towards the people with peace, covenant faithfulness, and tender mercy as if these were items that he has gathered up. AT: "I will no longer act towards them with peace, covenant faithfulness, and tender mercy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have gathered up my peace, covenant faithfulness, and acts of tender mercy

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of a person's actions as if the person were walking along a path. Here the word "heart" represents the mind or will. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:11:06|11:8]]. AT: "stubbornly doing the wicked things that he wants to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: walking by the stubbornness of his wicked heart

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of forcefully removing the people from the land as if he were throwing them from the land. AT: "force you to leave this land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: throw you from this land

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of enemy armies who will attack and kill the people as if they were fishermen who are catching fish. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will send for many fishermen ... so they will fish the people out

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of causing the land to be unacceptable to him as if the people had polluted the land. The words "their polluting" can be translated with a verbal phrase. AT: "because they have polluted my land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: for their polluting of my land

contextId.information: Jeremiah speaks of Yahweh as a place where enemies cannot attack him. He repeats the same idea three times. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: my stronghold and my refuge, my place of safety

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of others taking possession of all of Judah's wealth and territories as the price that Judah will have to pay for having sinned by worshiping idols. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: That is the price of your high places ... throughout all your territories

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the land as if it were an inheritance that he had given to the people of Judah as a permanent possession. AT: "You will lose the land that I have to you as an inheritance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will lose the inheritance that I gave to you

contextId.information: The emotions are spoken of as if they are centered in the kidneys. AT: "who tests people's desires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who tests the kidneys

contextId.information: Jeremiah compares the temple to a "glorious throne" because it is there that Yahweh dwells and rules. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The place of our temple is a glorious throne

contextId.information: Yahweh called Jeremiah to lead the people, like a shepherd leads his sheep. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a shepherd following you

contextId.information: Jeremiah's mother's womb would have held his dead body like tombs hold the bodies of dead people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: make my mother my tomb

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's punishment is spoken of as if it was a fire that would burn up those who did evil. AT: "I will punish and destroy you in my anger quickly and completely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my fury will go out like fire and burn

contextId.information: The results of their evil deeds is spoken of as fruit which grew from those practices. AT: "I will punish you as you deserve because of the things you have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have assigned the fruit of your practices to come against you

contextId.information: Yahweh refers to the land of Israel as if it were good pasture for his people. This good pasture is a metonym for provision for their needs. AT: "to good pasture" or "to where all their needs will be supplied" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to a grazing place

contextId.information: Here the emotion of fear is spoken of as if the prophet's bones were trembling. AT: "I am very afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: all of my bones tremble

contextId.information: This word probably stands here both for the literal idea that most men in the nation had committed adultery against their own wives, and also, as is common in biblical language, for the idea that they had abandoned Yahweh in order to worship idols. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: adulterers

contextId.information: AT: "it is like a great storm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a tempest is whirling about

contextId.information: AT: "I am about to drive you away from me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am about to pick you up and throw you away from me

contextId.information: This expression compares the exiles to a building which Yahweh will build and not tear down. AT: "I will help them flourish in the land, and not ruin them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will build them up, and not tear them down

contextId.information: Yahweh is commanding punishment to start. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cup of the wine of fury from my hand and make all the nations to which I am sending you drink it

contextId.information: AT: be punished" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: drink it

contextId.information: AT: "destruction is coming" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a great storm is beginning from the farthest parts of the earth

contextId.information: AT: "If you do not obey me and the law that I have given you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If you do not listen to me so as to walk in my law that I have placed before you

contextId.information: Here "hand" stands for the agency of these ambassadors. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: by the hand of those kings' ambassadors

contextId.information: AT: "But the nation who serves the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: But the nation that places its neck into the yoke of the king

contextId.information: This means that Yahweh has punished them so severely that there is no one that can help them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your injury is incurable ... for your wound to heal you

contextId.information: Yahweh describes the people of Israel as an unfaithful wife who takes lovers other than her husband. Here "lovers" refers to other nations. The Israelites allied with them and worshiped their gods instead of relying on Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: All of your lovers

contextId.information: This compares God's anger and punishment to a storm. This emphasizes his power and ability to destroy wicked people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: See, the tempest of Yahweh, his fury, has gone out

contextId.information: "on Zion, the high place" or "on Mount Zion." Being on top of hills is a metaphor for being happy. If your language associates mountain tops with sadness, it would be best to leave out the metaphor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: on the heights of Zion

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the Israelites as if they were a house or a food crop. AT: "in order to make them strong and many" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in order to build them up and to plant them

contextId.information: These words explain the metaphor about the sour grapes and the dulled teeth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For each man will die in his own iniquity

contextId.information: The city is spoken of as if it were a plant that someone could pull out of the ground or a building that someone could break down. This can be translated in active form. AT: "I will not allow anyone to pull up or overthrow the city again" or "No one will ever tear the city down or destroy it again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: The city will not be pulled up or overthrown again

contextId.information: "land where milk and honey flow." God spoke of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants were flowing through the land. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:11:03|11:5]]. AT: "land that is excellent for raising livestock and growing crops" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: land flowing with milk and honey

contextId.information: The large piles of dirt and rocks that the enemy built around the city so they could stand on them and attack it are spoken of as if they were the attackers themselves reaching out to capture the city. AT: "The enemy's seige mounds are so close to the city that the enemy will be able to capture the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The siege mounds have reached up to the city to capture it

contextId.information: A person being young is a metaphor for the people of Israel first becoming a nation. AT: "from the time they were young" or "from the time that they became a nation" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: since their youth

contextId.information: Honor is spoken of as if it were a solid object put in a container from which no one can remove it. AT: "I will cause them to always honor me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will set honor for me in their hearts

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of having his people live in the land forever as if he were planting plants in a garden. AT: "I will permanently settle the Israelites in this land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will faithfully plant them in this land

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of a descendant of David as if he were a branch off of a tree trunk. AT: "I will cause a righteous man to come from and bring glory to the line of David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will make a righteous branch to grow for David

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem as if the town were a woman. This can be translated in active form. AT: "this is what they will call her" or "this is what I will call the town" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: this is what she will be called

contextId.information: Walking after a god is a metaphor for obeying the laws of that god. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let no one walk any longer after other gods

contextId.information: This means that the king is in a difficult or helpless situation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your feet are now sunk into the mud

contextId.information: "I would present your urgent request to him." Telling the people's request to Yahweh is spoken of as if Jeremiah laid their requests in front of Yahweh. AT: "I might tell him your requests" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I might lay your pleas before him

contextId.information: Yahweh uses another example to express how he will cause the people of Israel to prosper and not be destroyed. He refers to them like a plant in the same way he referred to them as a wall. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I will plant you and not pull you up

contextId.information: Yahweh punishing people because he is very angry is spoken of as if wrath and fury were liquids that he poured out on the people. This can be stated in active. AT: "I became very angry and punished the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: my wrath and my fury were poured out on the inhabitants of Jerusalem

contextId.information: Yahweh punishing people because he is very angry is spoken of as if fury were a liquid that he pours out on the people. This can be stated in active. AT: "I will became very angry and punish you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: in the same way my fury will be poured out on you

contextId.information: Causing disasters is spoken of as if disasters were an object that can be put on something. AT: "all the disaster that I caused to happen to Jerusalem and all the cities of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: all the disasters that I brought on Jerusalem and all the cities of Judah

contextId.information: To stop doing something is spoken of as if it were physically turning away from something. AT: "or to stop behaving wickedly by burning incense to other gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: or turn from their wickedness in burning incense to other gods

contextId.information: Yahweh becoming angry and punishing the people of Judah is spoken of as his fury and wrath were a fire. AT: "and my fury and wrath were like a fire" or "and my punishment was like a fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and kindled a fire

contextId.information: Causing disaster to happen is spoken of as if disaster were an object that can be brought to someone. AT: "to cause disaster to happen to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to bring disaster to you

contextId.information: The invading army will be like woodcutters cutting down a whole forest. AT: "The Babylonian army will cut down the cities of Egypt." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will cut down the forests

contextId.information: The word "daughter" refers to the people of Dibon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sit on the dry ground, you daughter living in Dibon

contextId.information: Both 'horn' and 'arm' mean the same thing. They mean that Moab has been injured. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: The horn of Moab has been hacked off; its arm has been broken

contextId.information: The judgments which God sends upon Moab shall allow the country to be scorned by his enemies, just as a drunken man is the object of men's laughter and mocking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Make him drunk

contextId.information: This compares the people of Israel to a group of sheep that are lost. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lost flock

contextId.information: Here, "the hammer of all the lands" is the powerful army of Babylon that is going to be destroyed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: How the hammer of all the lands has been cut apart and destroyed

contextId.information: The young warriors are compared to bulls because of their strength. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Kill all her bulls

contextId.information: This phrase compares the fall of the once powerful nation of Babylon to an extremely loud noise and earthquake. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: At the sound of conquered Babylon the earth shakes

contextId.information: AT: "an unstoppable destruction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: wind of destruction

contextId.information: AT: "Babylon was a strong nation used for judgment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Babylon was a golden cup

contextId.information: These phrases compare the voice of Yahweh to the loud sound made by thunder and rain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When he thunders, there is the roar of waters in the heavens

contextId.information: Yahweh talks to Babylon as if it were a mountain which he could address as a person. Since mountains were sometimes the homes of bandits, it is possible that Jeremiah had this idea in mind here. See UDB. AT: "strong nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: mountain

contextId.information: Babylon's enemies have overcome her. "Waves" represent many people groups overcoming Babylon. The words "sea" and "water" often represent the nations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The sea ... roaring waves
